lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 11** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.
3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/duke/Laungher.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Launcher.main()`. If the setup is correct, you should see a GUI like the below:

implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-graphics', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'linux'
Duke is a personal chat-bot to help you keep track of your tasks, events, or deadlines.
It is optimized for keyboard users, but has a GUI for the looks as well.
- Ensure you have Java 11 or above installed in your Computer.
- Download the latest jar from the [release page](https://github.com/RezwanArefin01/ip/releases/).
- Copy the file to the folder you want to use as the home folder for your Duke.
- Make sure the directory has read and write permissions.
- Run `java -jar duke.jar` in a terminal to start Duke. A data directory will be created in the location you execute the command from.
- Do not use double click to start the application. Because your OS can decide to execute the command from a different place.
- [x] Add a task with a deadline.
## Add a todo task: `todo DESCRIPTION`
Adds a task with the given `DESCRIPTION`.
todo Return CLRS book to the library.
>   [üìù][ ] Return CLRS book to the library.
## Add a deadline task: `deadline DESCRIPTION / DATE TIME`
Adds a task with the given `DESCRIPTION` and a deadline specified by `DATE` and `TIME`.
- Number of digits in the day and month may be 1 or 2.
- Number of digits in the hour and minute must be 2.
## Add an event: `event DESCRIPTION / DATE TIME`
Adds an event with the given `DESCRIPTION` and a time specified by `DATE` and `TIME`.
Date and time format is the same as the deadline command.
Lists all tasks in the task list.
>   1. [üìù][ ] Return CLRS book to the library.
## Mark a task as done: `check INDEX`
Marks the task at the given `INDEX` as done.
You may want to use the `list` command to find the index of the task you want to mark as done.
>   [üìù][‚úî] Return CLRS book to the library.
## Mark a task as not done: `uncheck INDEX`
Marks the task at the given `INDEX` as not done.
>   [üìù][ ] Return CLRS book to the library.
Deletes the task at the given `INDEX`.
>   [üìù][ ] Return CLRS book to the library.
## Find tasks by keyword: `find KEYWORD`
Finds all tasks that contain the given `KEYWORD`.
Shows a help message with a list of commands and their usage.
Exits the program with a goodbye message.
All the data is saved in the file `./data/data.txt`, relative to the directory you execute the jar from.
You can modify task list by directly editing this file. Each line of the file describes one task.
TASK SYMBOL | IS DONE? | DESCRIPTION [| ARGS...]
- `TASK SYMBOL` is `T` for todo task, `D` for deadline, and `E` for event tasks.
- `IS DONE?` is 0 or 1 depending whether the task is due or not.
- `DESCRIPTION` is the description of the task.
- Currently, the `ARGS...` take in a date time for deadline and events. The date-time must be in the
format `h-M-yy HHmm`. Specifically, day and month number should not have leading zeros, and year must have
T | 0 | Return CLRS book to the library.
However, do note that if the data file is corrupted, Duke will not startup. It will show you a warning
about the corruption and you can choose to keep the file and investigate, or start with a new file.

+ "Check if the file permissions are set correctly.", ButtonType.OK);

* Parses a {@code Command} from a string.
* The format of the {@code Command} is {@code <command> <arg1> / <arg2> / ...}.
* The {@code <command>} must be one of the {@code CommandType}s.
* The case of the {@code <command>} does not matter.
* There must be at least one space before and after the {@code /}.

* Splits the input string into tokens.
* The first token is seperated from the rest by any amount of whitespace.
* The rest of the tokens (if any) are seperated by {@code " / "} with
* any amount of whitespace on either side.
// split the rest of the string by " / " and strip the tokens
// merge the first token with the rest of the tokens
* Parses a {@code Task} from a string.
* The format of the {@code Task} is {@code <task symbol> | <isDone> | <description> | <args> ...}.
* The {@code <task symbol>} must be one of the {@code TaskType}s.
* There should be exactly one space before and after the {@code |}.
* Returns the {@code TaskSymbolType} from an argument list of a Task.
* In case of an exception, the {@code input} is used to provide more information.
private static TaskSymbolType getTaskSymbolType(String[] splits, String input) {
throw new ParseException(input, "wrong number of arguments provided");

assertEquals("Parsing error: list todo (wrong number of arguments provided)", e.getMessage());

assertEquals("Parsing error: # | 0 | Task Description (unknown task symbol)", e.getMessage());

assertEquals("Parsing error: not an integer: 0  ", e.getMessage());
assertEquals("Parsing error: T | 0 description (wrong number of arguments provided)", e.getMessage());
assertEquals("Parsing error: T | 2 | Task Description (invalid isDone value)", e.getMessage());
assertEquals("Parsing error: not an integer: 1.3", e.getMessage());
assertEquals(new TodoTask("Task Description"), Parser.parseTask("T | 0 | Task Description"));
